cards.example: SELECT COUNT(*) FROM orders WHERE status = 'completed';
cards.explanation: COUNT(*) returns the total number of rows including NULLs. Use COUNT(column) to count only non-NULL values in a specific column.
COUNT(DISTINCT column) counts only unique values, removing duplicates. Perfect for counting how many different customers made orders.

cards.example: SELECT SUM(amount) FROM payments WHERE payment_date >= '2024-01-01';
cards.explanation: SUM() adds up all values in a numeric column. NULL values are ignored. Use with GROUP BY for subtotals.

cards.example: SELECT AVG(salary) FROM employees WHERE department = 'Engineering';
cards.explanation: AVG() returns the arithmetic mean of values. NULL values are excluded from the calculation.

cards.example: SELECT MIN(price) FROM products WHERE category = 'Electronics';
cards.explanation: MIN() finds the smallest value. Works with numbers, dates, and text (alphabetically first).
MAX() finds the largest value. Works with numbers, dates (most recent), and text (alphabetically last).

cards.syntax: SELECT col, agg() FROM table GROUP BY col
cards.example: SELECT department, COUNT(*) FROM employees GROUP BY department;
cards.explanation: GROUP BY groups rows that have the same values in specified columns. Each group produces one result row when combined with aggregate functions.

cards.syntax: SELECT col, COUNT(*) FROM table GROUP BY col HAVING COUNT(*) > value
cards.example: SELECT customer_id, COUNT(*) as orders FROM orders GROUP BY customer_id HAVING COUNT(*) > 5;
cards.explanation: HAVING filters groups after GROUP BY aggregates them. Unlike WHERE which filters rows before grouping, HAVING filters the grouped results.

cards.syntax: SELECT GROUP_CONCAT(col) FROM table GROUP BY col
cards.example: SELECT department, GROUP_CONCAT(name) FROM employees GROUP BY department;
cards.explanation: GROUP_CONCAT (MySQL) or STRING_AGG (PostgreSQL) combines values from multiple rows into a single string. Great for creating comma-separated lists.

cards.syntax: SELECT col, SUM(val) FROM table GROUP BY ROLLUP(col)
cards.example: SELECT region, product, SUM(sales) FROM sales_data GROUP BY ROLLUP(region, product);
cards.explanation: ROLLUP creates hierarchical subtotals. For GROUP BY ROLLUP(a,b), it creates groups for (a,b), (a), and grand total.

cards.syntax: SELECT col, SUM(val) FROM table GROUP BY CUBE(col1, col2)
cards.example: SELECT region, year, SUM(sales) FROM sales_data GROUP BY CUBE(region, year);
cards.explanation: CUBE generates subtotals for all combinations of columns. For 2 columns, creates subtotals for each column plus grand total.

cards.syntax: SELECT col, SUM(val) FROM table GROUP BY GROUPING SETS ((a), (b), (a,b))
cards.example: SELECT region, product, SUM(sales) FROM sales_data GROUP BY GROUPING SETS ((region), (product), (region, product));
cards.explanation: GROUPING SETS lets you specify exactly which grouping combinations you want. More flexible than ROLLUP or CUBE.

cards.syntax: WHERE filters rows, HAVING filters groups
cards.example: SELECT category, SUM(price) FROM products WHERE active = 1 GROUP BY category HAVING SUM(price) > 100;
cards.explanation: WHERE filters individual rows before aggregation. HAVING filters the grouped results after aggregation. Use WHERE when possible for better performance.
